title: Preterm prelabor rupture of membranes (PPROM)
text:
History of watery vaginal discharge.
Sterile speculum examination demonstrating liquor.
The role of ultrasound assessment of amniotic fluid volume is unclear.
Digital vaginal exam should not be done unless in labor.

title: Preterm prelabor rupture of membranes (PPROM)
text:
History of watery vaginal discharge.
Sterile speculum examination demonstrating liquor.
The role of ultrasound assessment of amniotic fluid volume is unclear.
Digital vaginal exam should not be done unless in labor.

title: Preterm prelabor rupture of membranes (PPROM)
text:
Investigations

Maternal:

CBC, CRP
Urine analysis and culture

Fetal:

CTG (if >28 weeks)
Ultrasound for growth and amniotic fluid volume

title: Preterm prelabor rupture of membranes (PPROM)
text:
Management

Admission. Outpatient management only by consultant decision (individualized).
Antibiotics:

Azithromycin 1 g PO single dose, plus
Penicillins (for 7 days):

Ampicillin-sulbactam 2 g IV q6h × 2 days, then
Amoxicillin 250 mg PO q8h × 5 days, plus


Antenatal corticosteroids if <34/<36 weeks (dexamethasone, after screening for GDM):

6 mg IM q12h × 4 doses, or
12 mg IM q24h × 2 doses

Magnesium sulfate for neuroprotection if <30/<34 weeks.


Birth

Timing:

<34 weeks: expectant management until 34 weeks, unless indicated earlier
34-<36 weeks: consider delivery after corticosteroids (individualized)
36-37 weeks: deliver

Indications for earlier delivery:

Chorioamnionitis
Fetal distress
Associated medical indications (e.g., severe preeclampsia)

Mode: VD unless CS is otherwise indicated.
Neonatologists should be informed when delivery is anticipated.

title: Preterm prelabor rupture of membranes (PPROM)
text:
Special considerations

Periviable ROM

<20 weeks → counsel regarding poor prognosis; risk of pulmonary hypoplasia, skeletal deformities, and neonatal death, in addition to risk of maternal morbidity from chorioamnionitis and sepsis.
20-<24 weeks → expectant management or termination of pregnancy after counseling.
24 weeks → expectant management.



Women with cerclage





Preterm labor

Tocolysis:



Chorioamnionitis

A combination of clinical assessment, maternal blood tests (CRP and WBC) and FHR should be used to diagnose chorioamnionitis in women with PPROM; these parameters should not be used in isolation.
Diagnosis: Maternal fever >38°C plus 2 of the following:

Maternal tachycardia >100 bpm
Fetal tachycardia >160 bpm
Uterine tenderness
Foul smelling vaginal discharge
Elevated WBC >15,000/mm3 (less reliable if corticosteroids given)

Management:

title: Preterm prelabor rupture of membranes (PPROM)
text:
Postpartum/preconceptional advice

Risk in subsequent pregnancies is increased.

title: Preterm prelabor rupture of membranes (PPROM)
text:
References

RCOG 2021
ACOG

title: About this site
text: This website provides management protocols for clinical practice at Ain Shams University Women’s Hospital. These protocols serve as evidence-based reference guides for healthcare professionals working within our institution.

title: About this site
text:
How protocols were developed
Each protocol was developed through a comprehensive review of current international guidelines, including those from NICE, RCOG, ACOG, SOGC, FIGO, and WHO. Relevant recommendations were then adapted to align with the our real-world capabilities, resources, and patient population.

This is a Quarto website.
To learn more about Quarto websites visit https://quarto.org/docs/websites.

title: About this site
text: This website provides management protocols for clinical practice at Ain Shams University Women’s Hospital. These protocols serve as evidence-based reference guides for healthcare professionals working within our institution.

title: About this site
text:
Development methodology
Each protocol was developed through a comprehensive review of available current international guidelines from NICE, RCOG, ACOG, SOGC, FIGO, and WHO. Evidence-based recommendations have been adapted to reflect our institution’s resources, and our patient population characteristics.

title: About this site
text:
Important disclaimer
These protocols are intended to support clinical decision-making but are not exhaustive and should not replace individual clinical judgment. Healthcare professionals must consider each patient’s unique circumstances and consult relevant specialists when necessary.

This is a Quarto website. To learn more, visit https://quarto.org/docs/websites.

Fetal:

title: Preterm prelabor rupture of membranes
text:
Management

Admission. Outpatient management only by consultant decision (individualized).
Antibiotics:

Azithromycin 1 g PO single dose, plus
Penicillins (for 7 days):

Ampicillin-sulbactam 2 g IV q6h × 2 days, then
Amoxicillin 250 mg PO q8h × 5 days, plus


Antenatal corticosteroids (dexamethasone) if <34/<36 weeks after screening for GDM:

Dose:

6 mg IM q12h × 4 doses, or
12 mg IM q24h × 2 doses

Repeat courses not routinely offeerred

Magnesium sulfate for neuroprotection if <30/<34 weeks.


Birth

Timing:

<34 weeks: expectant management until 34 weeks, unless indicated earlier
34-<36 weeks: consider delivery after corticosteroids (individualized)
36-37 weeks: deliver

Indications for earlier delivery:

Chorioamnionitis
Fetal distress
Associated medical indications (e.g., severe preeclampsia)

Mode: VD unless CS is otherwise indicated.
Neonatologists should be informed when delivery is anticipated.

title: Preterm prelabor rupture of membranes
text:
Special considerations

Periviable ROM

<20 weeks → counsel regarding poor prognosis; risk of pulmonary hypoplasia, skeletal deformities, and neonatal death, in addition to risk of maternal morbidity from chorioamnionitis and sepsis.
20-<24 weeks → expectant management or termination of pregnancy after counseling.
24 weeks → expectant management.



Women with cerclage





Preterm labor

Tocolysis is not recommended as it is associated with increased risk of chorioamnionitis.



Chorioamnionitis

A combination of clinical assessment, maternal blood tests (CRP and WBC) and FHR should be used to diagnose chorioamnionitis in women with PPROM; these parameters should not be used in isolation.
Diagnosis: Maternal fever >38°C plus 2 of the following:

Maternal tachycardia >100 bpm
Fetal tachycardia >160 bpm
Uterine tenderness
Foul smelling vaginal discharge
Elevated WBC >15,000/mm3 (less reliable if corticosteroids given)

Management:

Antibuotics:
Expedite delivery

title: Preterm prelabor rupture of membranes
text:
Postpartum/preconceptional advice

Risk in subsequent pregnancies is increased.

title: Reduced fetal movement
text:
flowchart TD
    Start[Woman presents with RFM] --> History[History & Risk Assessment]
    History --> Gestation{Gestation?}

    %% < 24 Weeks
    Gestation -->|< 24+0 weeks| Less24[Confirm Fetal Heart]
    Less24 -->|FH Heard| Reassure1[Reassure & Safety Net]
    Less24 -->|FH Not Heard| UrgentScan[Urgent Ultrasound]

    %% 24 - 28 Weeks
    Gestation -->|24+0 - 28+0 weeks| Btn2428[Confirm Fetal Heart]
    Btn2428 -->|FH Not Heard| UrgentScan
    Btn2428 -->|FH Heard| Risks24{Risk Factors for FGR/SB?}
    Risks24 -->|No| Reassure1
    Risks24 -->|Yes| Scan[Ultrasound: Growth, Liquor, Doppler]

    %% > 28 Weeks
    Gestation -->|> 28+0 weeks| More28[CTG Monitoring >= 20 min]
    More28 -->|Abnormal/Pathological| SeniorRev[Senior Obstetric Review]
    More28 -->|Normal| Risks28{Risk factors / Clinical concerns?}
    
    Risks28 -->|No| Measure[Abdominal Palpation/SFH]
    Measure -->|Normal Growth| Recurrent{Recurrent Episode?}
    Measure -->|Abnormal Growth| Scan
    
    Risks28 -->|Yes| Scan

    %% Scan Outcomes
    Scan -->|Normal| Recurrent
    Scan -->|Abnormal| SeniorRev

    %% Recurrent Loop
    Recurrent -->|No| Discharge[Discharge with detailed advice]
    Recurrent -->|Yes| SeniorPlan[Senior Review & Individual Care Plan]

    SeniorRev --> Management[Management: Delivery or Admission]

title: Hypertensive disorders in pregnancy
text:
Definitions & Classification

Chronic Hypertension: Hypertension present at the booking visit, or before 20 weeks, or likely to be chronic.
Gestational Hypertension: New hypertension presenting after 20 weeks without significant proteinuria.
Preeclampsia: New hypertension after 20 weeks with significant proteinuria (PCR \(\ge\) 30 mg/mmol) OR maternal organ dysfunction (renal, liver, neuro, haematological) OR uteroplacental dysfunction (fetal growth restriction).



Risk Reduction (Aspirin)
Prescribe Aspirin 75–150 mg daily from 12 weeks until birth if:

1 High Risk Factor: Hypertensive disease during a previous pregnancy, Chronic kidney disease, Autoimmune disease (SLE/APS), Type 1 or 2 diabetes, Chronic hypertension.
2 Moderate Risk Factors: Nulliparity, Age \(\ge\) 40 years, Pregnancy interval > 10 years, BMI \(\ge\) 35 kg/m\(^2\) at first visit, Family history of preeclampsia, Multifetal pregnancy.



Chronic hypertension

Pre-conception / First Trimester:

Stop ACE inhibitors, ARBs, and thiazide diuretics (risk of congenital abnormalities).
Substitute with Labetalol (1st line), Nifedipine modified-release (2nd line), or Methyldopa (3rd line).
Target BP: 135/85 mmHg.

Management:

Monitor BP weekly if poorly controlled, otherwise every 2–4 weeks.
Offer PLGF-based testing to rule out superimposed preeclampsia if suspected.
Timing of Birth: Offer planned birth at 37+0 weeks (or earlier if indicated). Continue treatment during labour.




Gestational hypertension

Assessment:

Urine dipstick at every visit. If \(\ge\) 1+, send for PCR/ACR.
Evaluate for symptoms of preeclampsia (headache, visual disturbances, epigastric pain, oedema).

Management:

BP 140/90 – 159/109 mmHg:

Offer anti-hypertensives: (1) Labetalol, (2) Nifedipine, (3) Methyldopa.
Target BP: 135/85 mmHg.
Monitor BP 1-2 times/week; Urine weekly.

BP \(\ge\) 160/110 mmHg (Severe):

Admit. Start treatment immediately.

Target BP: 135/85 mmHg.
Monitor BP 4 times/day minimum.

Timing of Birth: Offer planned birth at 37+0 weeks.



Preeclampsia

Assessment:

CBC, LFTs, Creatinine.

Management:

Mild/Moderate (140/90 - 159/109): Admit usually not required if stable. Treat to target 135/85 mmHg. Monitor BP 2x/week at least. Monitor fetal growth/dopplers (repeating every 2 weeks).
Severe (\(\ge\) 160/110): Admission required.

Antihypertensives: Labetalol (oral/IV), Nifedipine, Hydralazine.
Magnesium Sulfate: Give if severe features (severe headache, clonus, visual disturbance) or eclamptic seizure. Regimen: 4g IV loading dose over 5-15 min, then 1g/hr infusion for 24h.

Corticosteroids: Offer if < 34 weeks.

Timing of Birth:

Normally: Initiate birth at 37+0 weeks.
< 37 weeks: expectant management unless maternal/fetal compromise (uncontrolled BP, HELLP, eclampsia, placental abruption, severe FGR).




Postpartum management

Monitoring:

Measure BP daily for first 2 days.
If pre-eclampsia: At least 4 times/day while inpatient.

Medication:

Methyldopa: Stop within 2 days of birth (risk of depression).
Labetalol / Nifedipine / Enalapril: Safe for breastfeeding. Amlodipine is also an option.
Avoid diuretics if breastfeeding (may reduce milk supply).

Follow-up:

Transfer to community care if BP < 150/100 mmHg.
GP review at 2 weeks (medical review) and 6-8 weeks (postnatal check).

Future Health: Discuss long-term cardiovascular risks and lifestyle modifications.
